newsitem.title: USA: U.S. short-selling hedge funds tops in Oct - survey.
newsitem.headline: U.S. short-selling hedge funds tops in Oct - survey.

text.p: U.S. hedge funds that specialize in short selling recorded an 8.7 percent gain in October, far surpassing all other hedge fund types and the S&P 500, according to a report by Van Hedge Fund Advisors.

"A number of the stocks they (short-selling hedge funds) have been targeting all year in the technology sector and others experienced fairly significant corrections in October," said George Van, chairman of Van Hedge Fund Advisors.
The average U.S. hedge fund gained 1.3 percent last month, while the average offshore hedge fund rose 0.9 percent, the report said.

The best-performing hedge fund investment style so far in 1996 has been U.S. market neutral-securities hedging, which tries to profit from market anomalies without taking a position on whether the market will rise or fall. Fund managers employing that strategy have seen returns of 23.8 percent year-to-date.
Van said other investment styles that have risen strongly are U.S. emerging markets, up 23.4 percent; U.S. special situations, up 20.8 percent; and offshore aggressive growth, up 19.4 percent.
Hedge funds are private investment partnerships with wide latitude to invest across a variety of financial markets, frequently using borrowed money and derivatives.
Van Hedge Fund Advisors bases its performance index on a database of about 2,300 hedge funds managing more than $100 billion in assets.
